Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to the University of Nebraska-Lincoln that will provide research training for 10 students, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2013- 2015. The program focuses on bioenergy -- the application of molecular and physiologic principles using microbes, algae and plants to create renewable sources of energy thereby promoting a sustainable society. The School of Biological Sciences and the Center for Plant Science Innovation have 15 participating faculty who will serve as mentors. There is a wide range of very interesting and exciting projects for the students. Projects employ molecular biology, biochemistry and or genetics to understand energy dynamics in model species. Students are expected to do full-time lab research as well as participate in seminars and various workshops, such as the responsible conduct in research, professional communication skills, career opportunities in industry and academia, and the graduate school application process. Students are also provided tours of local industries of relevance to renewable energy production. REU students have access to a rich array of individual mentor's facilities as well as many interdepartmental labs and centers with core facilities such as electron microscopy, microarray analysis, surface analysis, etc. The program's multi-phase recruitment effort consists of both traditional "hard copy" formats as well as digital-based advertising. Students are selected based on academic record, research performance, and potential for outstanding research in biological engineering or quantitative biology. Students are tracked to determine their continued interest in their academic field of study, their career paths, and the lasting influences of the research experience. Information about the program will be assessed by various means, including use of an REU common assessment tool. More information is available by visiting http://www.unl.edu/summerprogram/research#bioenergy, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Paul Blum at pblum1@unl.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Heriberto Cerutti at hcerutti@unlnotes.unl.edu ).

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2013-2015, University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) microbiologists and plant biologists continued a highly successful NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site in the “Integrated Development of Bioenergy Systems”. The primary goals were to teach science to undergraduate students through active learning approaches and to encourage career decisions towards socially relevant scientific research.

Intellectual Merit. One of the greatest challenges facing 21st-century society is finding a sustainable energy supply. Energy is the basis for a large portion of the global economy and, currently, we are primarily dependent on nonrenewable fossil fuels. Not only are reserves dwindling, but the use of nonrenewable fossil fuels also contributes significantly to pollution and climate change. Biomass from plants, algae and cyanobacteria represents an abundant carbon-neutral renewable resource for the production of energy and biomaterials. Microbes offer efficient and sustainable ways to convert this biomass into liquid fuels or chemical feedstock. With adequate research and proper implementation, plants, algae, and other microorganisms have great potential to help address the energy crisis. To make this sustainable energy reality, however, there is a crucial need to train a new generation of scientists in bioenergy systems.

 The Microbiology Initiative (MBI) and the Center for Plant Science Innovation (CPSI) are interdisciplinary programs at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln charged with promoting innovative research that crosses traditional departmental boundaries. Together they have over 50 faculty members and over 150 graduate students undergoing training in bacteriology, archaea, virology, plant pathology, biology, biochemistry, biotechnology, chemical engineering, bioinformatics, genetics food science, agronomy, and molecular plant sciences. Both MBI and CPSI have received UNL University Program of Excellence (PoE) funds to foster innovative ways to develop, grow, and promote interdisciplinary research and training. A common theme inherent to these strong faculty clusters is the development of biological systems for energy production. The strategic implementation of PoE funds has allowed the MBI and CPSI to undertake strategic planning that includes a broadened mission particularly responsive to renewable energy needs. 

The specific objectives of the REU Site “Integrated Development of Bioenergy Systems”:

 Objective 1: Recruit and provide 10 undergraduate students per year a summer research experience in the laboratories of faculty focusing on microbiology and plant biology.

 Objective 2: Introduce participants to the diverse career paths available for researchers in bioenergy and stimulate debate on the best ways to achieve a sustainable national energy supply.

Objective 3: Provide a series of activities to prepare students for future opportunities in graduate education in areas related to bioenergy.

KEY OUTCOMES:
Broader Impacts. NSF funding allowed this program to over highly specialized training to 29 undergraduate students originating from diverse institutions across the United States. These students were selected from over 900 qualified applicants. All of the students completed the program requirements consisting of 10 weeks of laboratory training in bioenergy research, public scientific presentations of their work, and participation in seminars and workshops on ethics, professionalism, and STEM careers.
